You shouldn't be reading this review.

You should be experiencing an amazing game.

But if you want a short review in bullet point form then I can tell you this game has:

- Amazing puzzles and mechanics.
- Incredible level and sound design.
- A great sense of direction without waypoints (classic Valve).
- An awesome story with great funny characters.
- Amazing voice acting.
- Expert pacing.
- A great end-credits GLaDOS song.
- Some nice extra stuff like a comic book and funny videos.
- An awesome easy to use level creator.
- A single and multiplayer option to play user created levels.

This is an amazing experience you should not miss that I cannot recommend enough.

6/10 Decent:

Don’t kill me for offering a contrarian opinion here, but I think both Portal games are a victim of being overrated. I thoroughly enjoyed the first game, but not to the extent of the full whack of 10/10’s and ‘best game ever’ accolades that fans throw at it – it did, however, have an awesome villain and a fantastic ending song.

Portal 2 is a game of two halves. Initially, it kicks off by following on from the ending of Portal 1, and introduces the hilarious, Wheatley AI, a goofball in every sense of the word, rapid-fire, nonsensical ramblings that add a touch of comedy throughout.

He’s here to help you get out of the joint, and he’s awful at it. And of course, his incompetence leads to a certain villain showing up, and the two mesh well.

At this point, I was totally convinced the game was 9/10 awesomeness, both Wheatley and our villain were brilliant, superbly written and fun to interact with as we go through the typical Portal puzzles, using portals to navigate test chambers.

Where the game fell away for me was in Part 2. See, at the halfway point you get thrown out of the test chambers, I won’t elaborate on why, but suffice to say you get to use your portal gun in more open environments. You also get to incorporate ‘gels’ into your puzzle solving, so blue allows you to bounce higher, orange lets you run fast and white lets you create portals on any surface it comes in contact with.

It’s all neat, but the expanded world doesn’t really change up the puzzles (for me), it just makes them more tedious as I now have to scour the environment for the one flipping piece I can throw a portal on, figure out the mechanics and move on. And this breaks the pacing to such an extent that I just felt it became an entire slog.

The story also, doesn’t really pick up here, because we’re treated to a history lesson – which is nice, but in combination with the pace-breaking, it just doesn’t really entice me so much as it probably should.

This portion of the game was such a slog that it really killed the momentum of the first half, and it doesn’t help that it is more or less devoid of character interaction outside the historical blurbs. That’s what knocks the score down for me. Still, it’s a decent game, worth playing and it has an absolute army of fans that love it, so just treat my view as an anomaly in the pool, that’s science as our friendly villain would say.

Про Portal 2 нічого багато говорити. Чудова просторова головоломка, яка використовує систему порталів, проходження через них та переміщення сторонніх предметів. На перший погляд може здатися, що гра буде надто простою та одноманітною, проте це не так. Як тільки вам може почати набриднути ключовий геймплей, відразу ж розробники підкинуть щось нове: будь то кольорові гелі, що вводять нові механіки або бойові турелі. Сюжет простий як 5 копійок, проте він тут існує як головна сила, що рухає персонажа вперед по рівнях. Також захоплює аудіовізуальний стиль гри, який налаштовує на легкість, гумор та невимушеність довколишніх подій. Окремої уваги заслуговує кооперативна складова на двох гравців, оскільки змушує поглянути на проходження кімнат-головоломок з іншого кута. Відтепер єдиною запорукою успіху буде командна робота. Отож, чудовий вибір для бажаючих потренувати свою просторову уяву, та орієнтацію у просторі любителів ігор-головоломок.

Забежал в одну дырочку и выбежал из другой.

I miss the tight pacing and atmosphere of Portal, but Portal 2 improves on its predecessor in nearly every other way. Test chambers are made more complex thanks to the inclusion of the new gel mechanic, the difficulty curve is properly balanced, the campaign and its story is fleshed out this time around, a CO-OP campaign is present, and P2 has a great sense of humor. Portal 2 is easily the most unique gaming experience I've ever had. It's a nice break from the droves of shooters out on the market.

It's a great classic based around platforming, logical thinking, illogical physics, and witty writing. The main story isn't terribly long, and there's an alternate story line in the two-player cooperative mode. Add on countless community created testing chambers and a workshop to create your own, its playable from ten to hundreds of hours of solid gameplay.
